unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Two-Proportion $Z$-Interval

choices.text: How many times larger one proportion is than the other.
How many times smaller one proportion is than the other.
The sum of the two proportions.

solution:
A two-proportion $Z$-interval attempts to estimate the difference between the two proportions.

The difference (sample proportion $1$ - sample proportion $2$) is calculated, and then a margin of error is attached to this difference.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.

As an example, suppose a student wants to examine if gender plays a role of whether one is excited for prom or not. That student can take a random sample of boys and a random sample of girls and ask each group if they are excited about prom.

Perhaps based off sample data, the student finds that 80% of girls are excited about prom, while $72\%$ of boys are excited about prom. Based off the sample data, $8\%$ more girls are excited about prom than boys ($80\% - 72\% = 8\%$).

A two proportion interval hopes to give a range that represents the difference between all girls and boys in this context, not just the sample data. For example, perhaps the student calculates a margin of error of $2\%$ for this interval. Then, the student can attach this margin of error on either side of the interval in order to say we are $95\%$ confident between $6-10\%$ more girls in this high school are excited about prom than boys.
